div1.p: Cornell will accept donations of materials on yellow fever and will make available to him all their files.

div1.head: Letter from V.H. Cornell to Philip Showalter Hench, June 7, 1940
div1.opener:
THE AMERICAN REGISTRY OF PATHOLOGY
UNDER THE AUSPICES OF
NATIONAL RESEARCH COUNCIL
ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS
TO THE CURATOR
REGISTRY OFFICE
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM
WASHINGTON, D. C.
June 7, 1940
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Waldorf-Astoria Hotel,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Your letter of June 4 has just arrived and we shall
be very happy to receive for our files any information which you have
acquired concerning the yellow fever work of Walter Reed and his asso-
ciates. We should like very much to receive any photographs that you
may have secured which are not already in our files. Any information
or photographs that we have we shall be very glad to place at your
disposal.

Colonel Ash, Curator of the Army Medical Museum, is
at present attending several meetings in New York City, particularly
the American Medical Association and the American Society of Clinical
Pathologists. He is registered at the Tudor Hotel and should you
care to contact him you can probably reach him either there or through
the Registry Desk of either of the Societies.

We shall be very happy to greet you at the Museum
during your visit to Washington.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, V. H. CORNELL
Lt.Col., Medical Corps, U.S.A.
Acting Curator VHC/mgd
